questions.question_text:
A company has a business application hosted on Amazon EC2 instances behind an Application Load Balancer. Amazon CloudWatch metrics show that the CPU utilization on the EC2 instances is very high. There are also reports from users that receive HTTP 503 and 504 errors when they try to connect to the application.
Which action will resolve these issues?

discussion.content:
Answer is A. 5xx errors are server side (client side is 4xx). These server side errors correlate with the high CPU load. Putting into an ASG will allow horizontal scaling.
Not B. ALB health checks prevent unhealthy instances from trying to serve client requests. More frequent health checks won't change anything.
Not C. Sticky sessions are relevant if the load isn't truly balanced.
Not D. Idle timout is irrelevant. There is no need to increase the threshold for closing connections due to idling.
A. Place the EC2 instances into an AWS Auto Scaling group.
A is the answer
A. Place the EC2 instances into an AWS Auto Scaling group.
I'll go with A
Sounds like you need to scale, Answer A

Question mentions "Application Load Balancer not Classic" Then link is for classic.
So anyone sure it will work for application load balancer to ???
Because Option D can be used to resolve 504 error

choices.A: Place the EC2 instances into an AWS Auto Scaling group.
choices.C: Enable sticky sessions on the Application Load Balancer.
choices.D: Increase the idle timeout setting of the Application Load Balancer.
choices.B: Configure the ALB's Target Group to use more frequent health checks.
